newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish court declares Hestja insurer bankrupt.
newsitem.headline: Polish court declares Hestja insurer bankrupt.

text.p: A Polish court declared insurance company Hestja SA bankrupt on Wednesday and appointed another insurer, Polisa SA, as liquidator, PAP news agency reported.
Hestja administrative board chief Antoni Marciniak told the Poznan provincial court that at end-April 1996 the firm owed 16.2 million zlotys in payments on 8,000 claims, PAP said.
It had permanent assets of 300,000 zlotys and obligations arising from current policies of 10.2 million zlotys.
In addition Hestja, founded in Poznan, western Poland, in 1991, had 4.3 million zlotys of unlisted shares in a satellite communications firm and a carpet maker.
Hestja administrators said this month that U.S. firm World Health Network (WHN) had decided not to bid for Hestja after Poland's Insurance Guarantee Fund refused to back the move.
WHN had been ready to spend $10 million to cover Hestja's debts and raise its capital only if the fund guaranteed the investment.
An effort to secure further capital from shareholders had also failed to raise the expected sum, PAP said.
